results.abstract: Czech scientist Dr I Krivsky suggests that dangerous radiation from solar storm may have curtailed mission; says radiation was correctly forecast for late Oct and implies that Soviet officials were either unaware of forecast or failed to take it into acct, article in Prague newspaper Mlaba Fronta; Space Disturbance Forecast Center, Boulder, Colo, says major solar eruption occurred toward end of Soyuz flight; article in Pravda reveals preparations for capsule landing began on Oct 29; places landing area near Batpak, Kazakhstan

headline.main: SUN STORM CURBED SOYUZ, CZECH SAYS; Radiation Threat Proved Danger, Scientist Writes

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNION OF SOVIET SOCIALIST REPUBLICS PROJECTS

results.snippet: PRAGUE, Nov. 2 -- A scientist from the Czechoslovak Academy of Sciences' observatory suggested today that "very dangerous," radiation from a solar radio storm might have forced a premature ending of the orbital flight of the Soviet manned space...

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: PRAGUE, Nov. 2 -- A scientist from the Czechoslovak Academy of Sciences' observatory suggested today that "very dangerous," radiation from a solar radio storm might have forced a premature ending of the orbital flight of the Soviet manned space vehicle Soyuz 3 last Wednesday.
